title: Differential impact of heat stress on reef-building corals under different light conditions

affiliation.institution: Universit� e Pierre et Marie Curie

abstract: Heat stress is an environmental factor that regularly challenges the well-being of living organisms. This study aims to examine the physiological changes happening in two reef-building coral species exposed to thermal stress under various light conditions. The two ecologically relevant heatwave scenarios were applied under ambient lights (high irradiance) and reduced light conditions (250 and < 10 μmol photons m À s À 1). Corals were exposed to elevated temperatures of 32 � C (plus 6 �) for a period of 1 up to 5 days corresponding to heatwaves reported on the Great Barrier Reef (GBR) that were associated with coral bleaching. We monitored changes in the physiological performance of these two coral species by measuring symbionts and corals' physiological parameters including symbiont density, levels of multiple algal pigments (chlorophyll a and peridinin), as well as the changes in the host protein concentration. During the short-term heat stress, both species were with stable physiological performance with the only exception of Stylophora pistillata under ambient lights. These results show that S. pistillata was negatively influenced by a synergistic effect of temperature and high irradiance resulting in the first signs of bleaching after only 24h of thermal stress. Exposure to prolonged thermal stress, characterised with a slower rate of temperature increase, affected both coral species investigated and resulted in bleaching mainly by day 5. Interestingly, severe light reduction (<10 μmol photons m À 2 s À 1) made Acropora millepora corals more thermally sensitive and resulted in earlier signs of bleaching (on day 3). These findings indicate that there was a synergistic effect of very low lights and thermal stress that caused higher levels of bleaching in A. millepora. Our results revealed differential thermal sensitivity for two branching corals exposed to different thermal stress scenarios under various light irradiance conditions, naturally found in their existing habitats. Consequently, global warming may have a differential impact on coral reef biodiversity depending on light availability.

abstract.text: Heat stress is an environmental factor that regularly challenges the well-being of living organisms. This study aims to examine the physiological changes happening in two reef-building coral species exposed to thermal stress under various light conditions. The two ecologically relevant heatwave scenarios were applied under ambient lights (high irradiance) and reduced light conditions (250 and < 10 μmol photons m À s À 1). Corals were exposed to elevated temperatures of 32 � C (plus 6 �) for a period of 1 up to 5 days corresponding to heatwaves reported on the Great Barrier Reef (GBR) that were associated with coral bleaching. We monitored changes in the physiological performance of these two coral species by measuring symbionts and corals' physiological parameters including symbiont density, levels of multiple algal pigments (chlorophyll a and peridinin), as well as the changes in the host protein concentration. During the short-term heat stress, both species were with stable physiological performance with the only exception of Stylophora pistillata under ambient lights. These results show that S. pistillata was negatively influenced by a synergistic effect of temperature and high irradiance resulting in the first signs of bleaching after only 24h of thermal stress. Exposure to prolonged thermal stress, characterised with a slower rate of temperature increase, affected both coral species investigated and resulted in bleaching mainly by day 5. Interestingly, severe light reduction (<10 μmol photons m À 2 s À 1) made Acropora millepora corals more thermally sensitive and resulted in earlier signs of bleaching (on day 3). These findings indicate that there was a synergistic effect of very low lights and thermal stress that caused higher levels of bleaching in A. millepora. Our results revealed differential thermal sensitivity for two branching corals exposed to different thermal stress scenarios under various light irradiance conditions, naturally found in their existing habitats. Consequently, global warming may have a differential impact on coral reef biodiversity depending on light availability.

body_text.text: Coral reefs are one of the most species-rich habitats on Earth, hosting almost one-third of the world's marine fish species (Moberg and Folke, 1999) . Reef-building corals belong to the Scleractinia order and the vast majority form an obligatory symbiosis with photosynthetic unicellular algae, dinoflagellate from the family Symbiodiniaceae (LaJeunesse et al., 2018) . These unicellular algae live inside the tissue of hermatypic corals and provide oxygen, sugars, lipids, and amino acids to the coral host, in return for crucial nutrients like inorganic carbon, ammonia, and phosphate (Trench, 1979) . The symbiosis between corals and their dinoflagellate symbionts is sensitive to changes happening in the environment (van Oppen and Gates, 2006; Hoeksema and van der Meij, 2013) . One of the best visual indicators of ongoing stress on the reef is coral bleaching, which occurs due to the reduction of algal pigments and/or the numbers of symbiotic dinoflagellates within the tissue of the coral host (Hoegh-Guldberg and Jones, 1999) . Various environmental stress factors may contribute to bleaching including elevated seawater temperature, ocean acidification, and light stress including ultra-violet radiation (UVR) (Gates et al., 1992; Dunlap and Malcolm, 1998; Anthony et al., 2008; Rosic et al., 2014; Kaniewska et al., 2015) .

Incidents of mass coral bleaching have increased in intensity and frequency in recent decades (Hoegh-Guldberg et al., 2007) . Due to a record high sea temperatures during 2015/2016, a higher percentage of severely bleached reefs were reported compared to previous bleaching events on the GBR (Hughes et al., 2018) . Corals exposed to mild thermal stress may survive and recover their dinoflagellate symbionts, but typically they express reduced growth and calcification (Hoegh-Guldberg et al., 2007) and a decrease in coral productivity (Anthony et al., 2008) . Light irradiance, including both visible light and UV radiation, is another important factor for coral productivity and growth (Gates and Eomund, 1999; Bessell-Browne et al., 2017) . Light level decreases with the water depth following the Beer-Lambert law (Gordon, 1989) . The possibility of solar bleaching due to exposure to high light irradiance on its own without a combination with elevated temperature is reported to be only localised (Berkelmans, 2002; Brown and Dunne, 2015) . Some external factors such as low cloud cover and blue skies result in higher light levels and clear waters like described in the Gulf of Eilat, Red Sea (Winters et al., 2009) . Thermal stress combined with high irradiance has been reported to result in damage to host tissues and coral dinoflagellates (Lesser and Farrell, 2004) (Downs et al., 2013) . Higher temperatures have been found to promote bleaching susceptibility and mortality of the thermally sensitive corals by reducing the light intensity threshold, leading to photoinhibition and bleaching (Bhagooli and Hidaka, 2004) . The destructive effects of UVR on marine organisms were also reported for different marine species including corals and their algal symbionts (Lesser and Farrell, 2004) . Negative effects of UVR were described on dinoflagellate in culture resulting in decreased algal growth rates and reduced chlorophyll a concentrations (Dunlap and Malcolm, 1998) . Consequently, exposure to UVR has been recognized as an important abiotic factor leading to coral bleaching (Gleason and Wellington, 1993) , especially in combination with thermal stress (Torregiani and Lesser, 2007) .

In shallow waters, reduced irradiance was reported in the case of increased turbidity, after storms or due to human activities such as drilling (Hennige et al., 2008) . Very low irradiance in shallow waters was recently reported in the Pacific and was caused by huge floating rocks (>100 km 2 ), that were produced due to underwater volcanic eruption (Albeck-Ripka, 2019; Dockrill, 2019; Herbertson, 2019) . Lower irradiance conditions are also relevant to mesophotic corals found in deeper waters (Frade et al., 2008; Lesser et al., 2010) . Under reduced light levels, the thermal stress of þ4 � C above ambient temperature was found not to be sufficient to induce oxidative stress in bleaching sensitive Stylophora pistillata (Hawkins et al., 2015) .

Here, we explored the two thermal stress scenarios that in the past resulted in coral bleaching events on the GBR (Berkelmans, 2002; Dove, 2004) . Among the proposed strategies to mitigate the negative impacts of thermally induced stress is the use of reduced light levels during the periods of heatwaves with the aim to reduce the occurrence of bleaching on the GBR (Solomon, 2018) . In this study, for the first time, two coral species were exposed to three different light regimes during ecologically realistic heat stress scenarios. Using multiple physiological parameters, the aim of this study was to assess the ability of two shallow-water corals from the GBR to endure extreme heatwaves under reduced light conditions.

Two coral species Acropora millepora and Stylophora pistillata used in this study are both commonly found on the GBR (Fig. 1 ). These species are very abundant and therefore, critically important for building the coral reef ecosystem. Coral fragments were collected from the six different, visually healthy, colonies (displaying a full tissue pigmentation) of Acropora millepora and Stylophora pistillata. Sample collection occurred on the reef flat at Heron Island, Great Barrier Reef, Australia (23 � 25 0 S; 152 � 07 0 E) during the Australian summer (Nov 2013). Our Acropora millepora harbours Symbiodiniaceae, old classification Symbiodinium Clade C (LaJeunesse et al., 2003) , while Stylophora pistillata at shallow depths harbours Symbiodinium Clade C, genotypes C35a, C78a or C8a (Sampayo et al., 2016) . After collection, the coral fragments were divided using wire cutters into a single coral nubbin (~7 cm length) and immediately transferred to flow through aquaria to acclimatise for 48 h. Coral branches were randomly distributed across 18 aquaria, ~10 cm depth inside the aquarium with 3 aquaria per each experimental condition under the flow rate of ~0.4 L/min. Additional details and schematic presentation of the experimental settings are provided in Supplementary Fig. 1 .

Here, we applied ecologically relevant, stressful changes in temperature that were similar to the conditions previously reported in bleaching events (Berkelmans, 2002; Dove, 2004) under ambient light conditions and two reduced light levels (Supplementary Table 1 ). For the first thermal stress scenario lasting 1 day, i.e. the short-term thermal stress exposure (STE), in the control tanks (CTRL), coral nubbins (n ¼ 36) were exposed to ambient sea temperature at 26�1 � C. In the treatment tanks (TREAT) the temperature was incrementally increased, ~ 1 � C per 3 h, reaching a maximum of 32�1 � C. For the second thermal stress scenario lasting 5 days, coral nubbins (n ¼ 144) were kept under ambient temperatures (CTRL) and under heated conditions (TREAT), i.e. the long-term thermal stress (LTE) with the slow increase in temperature of ~ 1 � C per 10 h until reaching a maximum of 32�1 � C. For each of these thermal conditions, we used three light levels: (1) Ambient lights (AMB) with photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) ~ 1700 μmol photons m À 2 s À 1 ; (2) 'Low lights' (LL) with PAR ~ 250 μmol photons m À 2 s À 1 , mimicking natural light cycles with the 12-h light-dark cycle

(3) 'Very low lights' (VLL), PAR < 10 μmol photons m À 2 s À 1 . The VLL condition was maintained by using dark shade material to reduce lights and the 12-h light-dark cycle was used to simulate the natural light cycle. All light intensities were measured using a Li-Cor flat quantum sensor below the surface of the water in the tanks. Coral nubbins exposed to ambient lights received a total UV radiation ~70 W/m 2 /s measured using Jaz spectrometer (OceanOptics, Ft Lauderdale, FL, U.S. A) in the middle of the sunny day with a UVB proportion of ~0.35 W/m 2 /s. The fluorescent lamps above the aquarium produced a total UVR of 7.7 W/m 2 /s (measured above the water surface), while under very low light treatment spectral measurement with the Jaz spectrometer confirmed lack of UV. In order to mimic natural conditions that happen on the reef flat, day/night fluctuations in temperature (�2 � C) Fig. 1 . Picture of corals used in the study: Acropora millepora (A) and Stylophora pistillata (B) made by N. Rosic. were preserved during the experimental treatments via the use of the flow-through system. The sample collection step was performed by removing six nubbins (n ¼ 6) per treatment, from the experimental tanks under the CTRL and TREAT conditions. For STE conditions, the sampling was completed on days 0 and 1; while for LTE on days 0, 1, 3 and 5. The coral samples were snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen and kept at À 80 � C until further processing.

The frozen coral brunches were airbrushed and tissue was removed from the coral skeleton using a stream of air under pressure mixed with 0.06 M phosphate buffer (pH 6.65). The volume obtained was measured and then centrifuged at 5000xg, 4 � C, for 5 min. Two millilitres (mL) of supernatant was transferred into 2 tubes (1 mL each) and kept in a À 80 � C freezer, for further analysis of the total water-soluble host proteins. The pellet, containing the symbiont cells, was washed three to five times with 0.22 μm filtered artificial sea-water (FSW), to remove the mucus, then re-suspended in 3 mL FSW and divided into 3 aliquots (1 aliquot to be used for the cell count, and 2 for further pigment analyses) and stored at À 80 � C. The tubes were kept on the ice during the whole processing time. To be able to compare our experimental data (micro-algal cell density, algal pigment, and host protein concentration) afterward, data were normalised to the skeleton surface area. The measurement of the surface area of the coral skeleton was done using the paraffin wax method (Stimson and Kinzie Iii, 1991) .
body_text.section: Airbrushing, sample preparation, and measurement of the coral skeleton surface area

body_text.text: The symbiont cell density was calculated using a hemocytometer (Improved Neubauer). The cell count per sample was done 8 times using the 25 squares in the centre (1 mm 2 /0.1 mm depth). The total number of cells was then re-calculated taking into consideration the previous dilution factor used during measurement. The final algal cell number was normalised to the surface area (cm 2 ) of the skeleton (see above).

To determine the level of total water-soluble proteins, corresponding to corals energy reserves, host proteins were isolated from the tubes containing the tissue supernatant obtained after airbrushing. Absorbance values were determined at 235 nm and 280 nm in a SHIMADZU UV 2450 spectrophotometer and host protein concentrations were estimated following the method used by Whitaker (Whitaker and Granum, 1980) . The total quantity of proteins was then calculated and reported for the surface area of the skeleton, considering dilution factors and the volume of phosphate buffer solution used during the airbrushing procedure.
body_text.section: Protein assay of total water-soluble proteins

body_text.text: The dinoflagellate cells obtained from the pellet after airbrushing were used for pigment extraction. All processes were done in the dark (or minimum luminosity) and cold, to prevent pigment degradation. After centrifugation (5000xg, 5 min, 4 � C), the FSW was removed, and the pellet re-suspended in 1 mL of ice-cold 100% methanol. The suspension was then mixed by vortex, homogenized with a pipette, followed by sonication on ice-cold water for 10 min, and centrifugation (5000xg, 5 min, 4 � C). The supernatant was collected and transferred into a clean tube. Another 1 mL of ice-cold 100% methanol was added to the pellet again, and the mixing and centrifugation were repeated three times or more until the pellet became completely white. Then, the combined supernatant, containing the pigments, was filtered (using a 0.22 μm filter) and 300 μL was used for the reverse-phase High-Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC) analyses. Pigments were separated using a Shimadzu SCL-10 HPLC linked to a Shimadzu SPD-M10A photodiode array detector. We used a Phenospere 5 μm C8 80A HPLC column (Phenomenex, Australia) and the method of Zapata et al. (2000) . The two solutions were used in this HPLC method including: mobile phase A (methanol: acetonitrile: ammonium acetate buffer solution; 50:25:25 v:v:v) and mobile phase B (methanol: acetonitrile: acetone solution; 20:60:20 v:v:v). The obtained pigment profiles were compared to standards from DHI Water (Denmark).
body_text.section: Extraction and measurement of photosynthetic pigments

body_text.text: Statistical analyses were performed using the statistical software Statistica 12.0 (Statsoft Inc., Dell) and SPSS Statistics (version 24). Data normality was tested using the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test and Levene's test for homogeneity of variance, and where assumptions were violated, the data were corrected by transformations. The effects of experimental conditions between control and treatment were analysed using parametric tests (ANOVA and paired two-tailed t-test). The influence of factors or interactions of factors was tested by performing a factorial ANOVA. The Tukey's Honest Significant Difference test was applied for post hoc comparison of the means. Values were considered significantly different where P < 0.05. In this paper, data are expressed as means � standard error.

For A. millepora, short-term thermal stress that lasted for a 24-h period that took ~18 h to achieve þ6 � C (1-degree increase every 3 h), did not significantly affect any of the physiological parameters measured (Fig. 2) . On the other hand, the experimental treatments had a significant effect on S. pistillata (two-way ANOVA, Table 1 ). A significant reduction was measured in all physiological parameters when S. pistillata was exposed to heat stress under ambient lights (t-test: P < 0.05), but not under the reduced light intensity (LL and VLL). Within the S. pistillata tissue exposed to thermal stress and high irradiance ambient lights, a 6.9-fold decrease in symbiont density was reported including the reduction in algal pigments chlorophyll a and peridinin concentrations, as well as host protein concentration ( Fig. 2; Supplementary Table  2 ). These changes in S. pistillata indicate physiological alterations corresponding to the phenomenon of bleaching in heated corals under ambient light conditions.

Prolonged thermal stress, incrementally reached þ6 � C after ~60 h (1-degree increase every 10 h). In A. millepora, the sensitivity to bleaching was influenced by thermal stress, and time, as well as light conditions in the case of host proteins (three-way ANOVA Table 2 ). In heat-stressed A. millepora, initial measurements on day one and day three were within the healthy range and comparable to the control values for the majority of physiological parameters (Fig. 3) . The only exception and the first signs of bleaching were noted earlier under VLL on day 3, with a 2.7 fold reduction in algal density, a drop in algal pigments (6-and 10-fold, for chlorophyll a and peridinin respectively) and a 1.4-fold reduction in the host protein content (Supplementary Table 2 ). On day 5, under all light conditions, a decline in physiological parameters was observed for all heated corals (P < 0.05). The algal density on day 5 dropped for 1.7-, 3-and 54-fold for the AMB, LL and VLL treatments respectively ( Fig. 3; Supplementary Table 2 ). The concentration of algal pigments was also significantly reduced after 5 days of exposure to heat stress with declines of 2-and 46-fold in chlorophyll a concentration under AMB and VLL (P < 0.05), but not under LL conditions (P > 0.05). The concentration of pigment peridinin on day 5 was lower in corals exposed to reduced lights with declines of 7-fold at LL and 25-fold at VLL, but not under ambient lights. Similar trends were observed for the host protein levels ( Fig. 3; Supplementary Table 2) , with a 2.6-fold reduction under LL and a 13-fold decrease under VLL.
body_text.section: Long thermal stress in A. millepora

body_text.text: Corals kept at ambient temperature (~26 � C) appeared visually healthy during the duration of the experiment. This health status was confirmed in the samples of A. millepora, kept in aquaria at ambient temperature (~26 � C) under ambient lights, as the algal density and chlorophyll a concentration remained overall stable during the 5-day experimental period (P > 0.05). These results demonstrate that bleaching was not triggered in corals kept under the control conditions (ambient temperature and ambient lights).
body_text.section: Long thermal stress in A. millepora

body_text.text: The P-values and F values of the two-way ANOVA analyses that tested physiological changes in coral Stylophora pistillata due to the short-term thermal stress exposure (STE) lasted for 1-day under three light levels (ambient, low and very low lights).

Statistical analysis (three-way ANOVA) of the effects of light, temperature and time on the physiology of Acropora millepora and Stylophora pistillata due to the long-term thermal stress exposure (LTE) lasted for a 5-day period under three light levels (ambient, low and very low lights).

The effects of light, temperature and time on physiology revealed that thermal stress and time, but not light conditions had a significant effect on measured algal physiological parameters in S. pistillata (Table 2) . The main effect of temperature and time was significant on the coral protein level, including the significant impact of the interaction between multiple factors (light x temperature x time; Table 2 ). For S. pistillata, a significant change in the symbiont density (cell numbers/ cm 2 ) was observed in heated corals after 5 days of thermal stress compared to corals at ambient temperature (Fig. 4) . Algal concentrations dropped for 7-fold at AMB, 9-fold at LL and even 24-fold at VLL (P < 0.001). A reduction in algal pigments (μg/cm 2 ), was also observed with prolonged thermal stress with declines in the chlorophyll a levels of 9-fold at AMB; 10-fold at LL and even 125-fold at VLL (P < 0.019). For peridinin, there was an 8-fold decrease at AMB; a 5-fold reduction at LL and a huge drop of 31-fold at VLL (P < 0.01). There was also a significant loss of host proteins compared to the control samples after 5 days, with declines of 2-, 3-and 9-fold observed for the AMB, LL and VLL treatments respectively (Fig. 4, Table 2 ).
body_text.section: Long thermal stress in S. pistillata

body_text.text: To confirm that ambient temperature did not lead to bleaching in the S. pistillata control samples, the concentration of chlorophyll a and areal algal density (cells per cm 2 ) were analysed. During the 5-day period of the experiment, under ambient lights, chlorophyll a was stable (P > 0.05); there was a significant effect of time on symbiont density (oneway ANOVA, P ¼ 0.001) between the control samples from days 0 and 3 (Tukey, P ¼ 0.002) and days 0 and 5 (Tukey, P ¼ 0.006). A significant difference in symbiont density was noted between ambient and LL control conditions in S. pistillata (Tukey, P ¼ 0.034). Under LL lights, both chlorophyll a level and areal symbiont density were stable during the 5-day experiment (P > 0.05). Under VLL, chlorophyll a concentration was also unchanged over 5 days (P > 0.05), while symbiont density was affected between the control coral samples at days 0 and 5 days (Tukey P ¼ 0.025). These results demonstrate that there was a drop in symbiont density as a result of a prolonged time in aquaria that affected the control samples. However, these slight differences were comparable in both control and heated samples and not significant until day 5 (Fig. 4) . Consequently, bleaching was not triggered in S. pistillata control samples kept in aquaria at ambient temperature and light conditions.
body_text.section: Long thermal stress in S. pistillata

body_text.text: The changes in climate are causing the deterioration of coral reefs across the globe (Gardner et al., 2003) . In the current study, we exposed the two bleaching sensitive corals to thermal stress at 32 � C (þ6 � C) under various light conditions including ambient lights and reduce light irradiance. These ecologically realistic temperature variations were reported to lead to coral bleaching in the past (Berkelmans, 2002; Dove, 2004) .

Under short term thermal stress of þ6 � C, lasting 24h, negative effects on measured physiological parameters were observed for S. pistillata but not for A. millepora corals. The harmful effect on the physiology of S. pistillata was noted only when heated corals were exposed to high irradiance ambient lights. These results demonstrated that acute thermal stress and high irradiance synergistically caused the bleaching effect. However, at low irradiance conditions, corals were able to endure heat exposure over 24 h without changes in physiological performance. Similarly, in the Caribbean coral, Montastraea faveolata, heat stress was the principal cause for coral bleaching when exposed to high irradiances (Lesser and Farrell, 2004) . S. pistillata is a very common coral species found on the GBR particularly under high light irradiance and is normally able to endure unstable environmental conditions (Loya, 1976) . Improved thermo-tolerance was reported for S. pistillata and another branching corals from the Gulf of Aqaba after 4 weeks of exposure to þ4 � C under low light intensity conditions (Bellworthy and Fine, 2017) . However, after short thermal stress, the threshold light intensity leading to photoinhibition in thermally sensitive coral S. pistillata was lower at 32 � C (þ10 � C) compared to 26 � C (þ4 � C) (Bhagooli and Hidaka, 2004) . Here, we did not observe bleaching under reduced lights at 32 � C (þ6 � C), but under high irradiance accompanied by a strong UVR level. In coral dinoflagellates kept in cultures, when heat stress was combined with UVR, oxidative stress and inhibition of photosynthesis were reported (Lesser, 1996) . However, high irradiance without heat stress was not found to be sufficient to cause bleaching, except when combined with elevated temperatures (Berkelmans, 2002) . The absence of light stress was found to mitigate the negative impacts of temperature increase (þ4 � C) in terms of the absence of oxidative damage (Hawkins et al., 2015) . The fact that rapid thermal stress had an effect after only one day on S. pistillata under high irradiances, but not under reduced lights, indicates the combined synergistic effects of temperature and high UV radiation causing bleaching.

The absence of signs of bleaching on A. millepora for the short-term experiment does not mean necessarily that short-term thermal stress did not affect A. millepora at all. The short acute thermal stress may not be long enough to observe physiological variations like those observed for another branching coral Acropora aspera (Rosic et al., 2014) . The lack of physiological changes in A. millepora after only 1-day of thermal stress needs to be followed up on a molecular level as first changes are often happening at the level of gene expression before physiological and visual signs of bleaching can be observed (Rosic et al. 2010 (Rosic et al. , 2013 Leggat et al., 2011; Bellantuono et al., 2012) .

The second bleaching scenario, which included prolonged thermal stress over a 5-day period with ~3x slower heating rate compared to the STE treatment. Here, the incremental rise in temperature achieved 32 � C after ~2.5 days and corals bleaching thresholds for both examined coral species showed roughly similar patterns. Relative to the equivalent temperature control treatment, the majority of heated corals were visually and based on physiological parameters healthy on day 3. However, following day three, a reduction in symbiont density, algal pigments, and host water-soluble proteins became evident by day five. For another branching coral A. aspera from the shallow waters of Heron island (GBR), there were no signs of bleaching after 3 days of thermal stress under ambient lights (Rosic et al., 2014) , but bleaching was confirmed after 4 days of heat stress (Fisher et al., 2012) . Earlier signs of bleaching were observed here after 3 days in heated A. millepora under VLL, but not under ambient and LL. Elevated temperatures plus very low light conditions, in this case, may have a synergistic effect resulting in advanced bleaching than what might occur in regular photosynthetically productive conditions. Reduced light levels were described in shallow waters due to the increased turbidity like that seen after storms (Hennige et al., 2008) or after the underwater volcanic eruption (Albeck-Ripka, 2019; Dockrill, 2019; Herbertson, 2019) . Organisms respond to changes in light intensity via the process of photo-acclimation (Titlyanov et al., 2001; Anthony and Hoegh-Guldberg, 2003; Hennige et al., 2008; Lohr et al., 2019) . However, in shallow and turbid waters, reduced light conditions have been reported to negatively impact photosynthesis and calcification in Acropora tenuis and to lower the corals' energy balance (Strahl et al., 2019) . The host protein concentration in heated A. millepora corals was significantly reduced just after 3 days compared to controls under VLL, suggesting an increased sensitivity of corals to bleaching under reduced lights.

Host cells have a flexible, but finite capacity for symbiotic cells, and must, therefore, regulate algal numbers (Muscatine et al., 1998) . Regulatory processes include degradation or digestion of existing symbionts (Titlyanov et al., 1996) , as well as the expulsion of intact symbionts (Hoegh-Guldberg et al., 1987) , both of which can lead to bleaching. In response to environmental changes, these processes allow corals to save energy, by diminishing the amount of energy used to maintain existing symbionts (Dimond and Carrington, 2008) . The increased thermal sensitivity of A. millepora under VLL was not noted for S. pistillata indicating the higher dependence on photosynthetic products in A. millepora. On the other hand, S. pistillata was not affected by prolonged thermal stress so early on under VLL and was possibly capable of obtaining the carbon via means other than photosynthesis. Interestingly, no signs of bleaching were observed in S. pistillata on day 3 under high irradiance conditions. These conditions were in some ways equivalent to the end of the short-term experiment, with a difference in ~3x slower temperature increase and double time at 32 � C (12h). It seems that there was no interaction between thermal stress and high UV as seen at STE for S. pistillata, possible due to a slow change in temperature. Consequently, a slower increase in temperature to þ6 � C, possibly resulted in higher thermal tolerance and postponed the detrimental bleaching process. In another study, S. pistillata exposed to mild heat stress þ4 � C had a higher photoinhibition threshold than when exposed to more severe þ10 � C (Bhagooli and Hidaka, 2004) . Consecutive exposure to heatwaves resulted in acclimatisation and an increase in the thermal tolerance of massive long-lived Porites corals from GBR (DeCarlo et al., 2019) . Consequently, our findings indicate that the thermal sensitivity of coral species under various light environments may be influenced by both heatwave profiles, light conditions, and specifically UV level. Therefore, light availability may be a critical factor, which affects not only the distribution of corals but also their response to increasing incidences of heatwaves.

The results of this study demonstrate the difference in thermotolerance in two coral species exposed to two heatwave scenarios under different light conditions. Differential bleaching profiles were detected, with S. pistillata seeming to be more sensitive to short term thermal stress than A. millepora. Nevertheless, short term acute exposure to thermal stress was detrimental to S. pistillata only when combined with a strong effect of UV radiation, resulting in a bleaching effect. In A. millepora, potentially synergistic effects of very low light and prolonged thermal stress may have caused higher levels of bleaching than what might occur under high irradiance. Consequently, depending on the heating rates, the light conditions may be a tipping point towards postponing or speeding up the bleaching progression. Subsequently, global warming under diverse light intensities and UV radiation will jointly influence coral bleaching modelling maps and have a clear impact on reef biodiversity and the coral community composition.
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

back_matter.text: This work was supported by a University of Queensland Postdoctoral Fellowship for Women and a Discovery Early Career Researcher Award (DECRA) to NNR. We thank A/Prof Sophie Dove on the critical input on this manuscript, Johanna Torres for her help during the fieldwork and also Dr Annamieke Van Den Heuvel on her support in the laboratory activities.
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.marenvres.2020.104947.

BIBREF0.raw_text: Albeck-Ripka, L., 2019. A raft of floating rock stuns sailors. But can it save the reef?. In: The New York Times https://www.nytimes.com/2019/08/27/world/australia/pum ice-raft-coral.html.

FIGREF1.text: Symbiodiniaceae density, chlorophyll a, peridinin and host protein concentrations in Acropora millepora during long-term exposure (LTE) experiment under different light conditions: ambient lights (AMB), low lights (LL) and very low lights (VLL). FIGREF2.text: Symbiodiniaceae density, chlorophyll a, peridinin and host protein concentrations in Stylophora pistillata during long-term exposure (LTE) experiment under different light conditions: ambient lights (AMB), low lights (LL) and very low lights (VLL).
